utterances: (Soundbite of crowd chanting)
Join us, join us, the crowds roared as they marched.
And it seemed with each passing minute, the crowds became larger and larger.
Down with the lies, down with the dictator, they cried - give us our votes back.
Then the riot police arrived - the ninjas, as the protestors called them - outfitted like they just stepped out of a video game with body armor, helmets and facemasks.
They were on motorcycles with backfiring engines that sounded like gunshots meant to strike fear in the crowds.
But the crowds stood their ground and mocked the riot police.
(Soundbite of protestors)
The police began to beat the demonstrators.
Some protestors knocked a few police down and set the cycles on fire.
The police responded fiercely.
One young woman described what happened to her.
They tripped a woman, she fell down in the puddle.
I went to help her and I take her out in a restaurant.
They just riot in the restaurant, break into the restaurant and hit all of us.
The young woman, who preferred not to use her name, expressed the anger and frustration that many in Iran feel right now.
They believe the election was stolen from the real winner, Mir Hossein Mousavi.
There is no democracy.
We don't need this government.
We don't need (unintelligible) Ahmadinejad.
We did not vote for him.
(Soundbite of car horns)
British singer/songwriter Paul Weller's career has spanned 30 years and many pop styles.
DAY TO DAY music critic Christian Bordal spoke with Weller during the singer's recent US tour, and he has this mixed reaction to the latest CD.
It's called ""As Is Now.
These clashes occurred on boulevards still choked with cars.
Each time the motorized riot police would snake through traffic or fly down the sidewalks, motorists joined in a hail of car horns to alert the protestors that police were on the move.
One man in the crowd, who also preferred to remain nameless, appealed to the outside world for support.
This is a war - government over the war.
Really I ask world to help our people.
Please, please, please help our people.
Encourage us.
So far the demonstrations against President Ahmadinejad had been spontaneous and unorganized.
The government has made it difficult for the opposition to coordinate actions by shutting down text messaging and the cell phone system.
Last night the government shut down the cell phone network entirely and closed down the Internet as well.
Demonstrations have not been confined to Tehran.
Similar clashes had been reported in Shiraz in the south, in Esfahan and several other cities.
There are also reports that several prominent figures in the pro-Mousavi camp have been arrested.
The whereabouts of Mousavi himself has been a mystery for nearly two days now.
His Web site issued a statement condemning the election as a fraud.
The official results gave Ahmadinejad some 63 percent of the vote to Mousavi's 34 percent.
Late Saturday night, Ahmadinejad appeared on state television to claim a great mandate.
Not only had he won, he said through an interpreter, but he received more votes than any other candidate for president in the history of the Islamic Republic of Iran.
(Through translator) Nearly 40 million people took part in a total of three elections, which means in itself, this sets a record by itself - a great record in all of the world.
I chose the path to the future, a path of dignity and pride.
Late today, Ahmadinejad addressed thousands of his supporters at a victory rally in central Tehran.
Mousavi supporters were planning a march of their own later tonight.
Mike Shuster, NPR News, Tehran.
Our next story may not be suitable for young ears, so you may want to shield them now.
Two former University of Colorado football players - one now in the NFL - could face rape charges soon.
The allegations date back to a 2004 recruiting scandal.
A local district attorney said the university was using alcohol and sex to lure high school athletes to play for the team.
Since then, Colorado reformed its recruiting program and, at the time, no charges were brought against several athletes accused of rape.
That, as NPR's Jeff Brady reports, may be about to change.
Nine years ago, almost exactly, Julie Stene was graduating from high school.
She says she went to a party, got very drunk, blacked out and at three in the morning woke up in her carâ€¦
In only a T-shirt with mud on myself and in a lot of pain, and I knew that I had been sexually assaulted.
Stene went to the police, who took her to a hospital for tests.
DNA from two people was collected from Stene.
One matched classmate Clyde Surrell, who told police they had consensual sex.
At first, Stene was prepared to help prosecutors, but then her father became terminally ill.
She was depressed and dropped out of the case.
Then in 2004, the scandal at the University of Colorado was making headlines.
Stene knew Surrell was a player there.
And I thought, oh god, if he's involved in this, I'm going to feel really, really bad because I could have pressed charges against him and maybe this wouldn't have happened.

Stene decided she was strong enough to go ahead with the case at that point, but according to court documents, the prosecutor refused to file charges, saying she didn't want to appear to be piling on the University of Colorado bandwagon.
Stene's own lawyer then filed a rare civil suit to compel prosecution, and the judge has ordered just that.
I felt so alone for nine years and now I finally feel like I have people behind me.
So, you have no idea what that feels like.
It's very empowering.
NPR couldn't reach Clyde Surrell for this story.
Phone numbers connected to his name were disconnected and lawyers who represented him in the past say they've had no contact with him.
But in 2007, he talked with Denver television station KUSA.
If I've ever heard a girl say stop, I'm done.
I'm out of there.
I do not want to get involved.
I've just been like that.
And like I told you before, I'm not the aggressive type.
Julie Stene says another former classmate also raped her that night.
Riley McMurdo says he's innocent.
His attorney, Iris Eaton, says she may challenge the judge's decision to compel the prosecutor to file charges.
You have a situation where a career prosecutor made the decision not once, but she made it three times not to file this case.
She said there's no case.
Eaton says her client didn't even know the case was being brought back up until a reporter called him.
And the judge's order that has revived this case, a completely separate case is mentioned involving another woman, Monique Gillespie.
She says she was raped by Clyde Surrell and another football player in December of 2001.
Gillespie says that other player is Marques Harris, who is now a professional football player with the San Francisco 49ers.
The Boulder County District Attorney's Office says it's reviewing those allegations to determine if charges are warranted.
Attorney Lou Rubino is representing Harris and says it's a shame this issue has resurfaced.
What's the expression, old wine in new bottles?
(Soundbite of laughter)
It's just a dead issue.
It should be a dead issue.
It's been hashed and rehashed.
And, again, Marques Harris did nothing wrong.
Rubino says Harris passed a polygraph test and submitted DNA samples back in 2001.
He suspects prosecutors will conclude again that there's not enough evidence.
Jeff Brady, NPR News, Denver.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Noah Adams.

In his long career, Paul Weller has been all over the pop and rock music map.
His first band, The Jam, was the most popular British punk band of them all.
(Soundbite of music)
(Singing) ...(Unintelligible).
The Jam played gigs with The Sex Pistols, The Clash, The Buzzcocks, but Weller says he's perfectly happy to have left those crazy days behind.
The gigs were so violent at that time.
I mean, every single gig around that time ended in a fight or some sort of kind of chaos or mayhem.
So I don't really miss that.
In '82 at the height of their popularity, Weller broke up The Jam and started playing a sleek, chic synthesized take on American soul and R&B.
With his new band, The Style Council, he helped usher in the '80s new wave sound of groups like the Eurhythmics.

(Singing) I wish to stay forever letting this be my (unintelligible).
Oh, but I'm caught up in a whirlwind of my ever-changing moods.
